abstract.p: Daniel Simidor letter on Lt George Mole's June 17 article scores police shooting of Amadou Diallo and lauds Bruce Springsteen's song; drawing

block.p: George Mole, a police lieutenant, has gone sour on Bruce Springsteen's music, faulting his song ''American Skin'' for ''implying, viciously, that the police killed Amadou Diallo because he was black'' (Op-Ed, June 17). The real outrage is the barrage of 41 bullets that the four undercover police officers shot at the unarmed Mr. Diallo and the travesty of justice that exonerated them.

George Mole, a police lieutenant, has gone sour on Bruce Springsteen's music, faulting his song ''American Skin'' for ''implying, viciously, that the police killed Amadou Diallo because he was black'' (Op-Ed, June 17). The real outrage is the barrage of 41 bullets that the four undercover police officers shot at the unarmed Mr. Diallo and the travesty of justice that exonerated them.

The usual police excuse, which Lieutenant Mole repeats -- that the frail Mr. Diallo ''fit the general description of a man who had committed numerous rapes'' -- is racial profiling. The fact is that no young white man, regardless of the circumstances, would have been run down and killed the same way that night. Mr. Springsteen is to be commended for writing a courageous song and for breaking with the tacit racial allegiance lawless police officers have come to rely on.
The writer is a Haitian community activist.
